PETE:Â  Itâ€™s partly just for that thing of wanting to keep the event loop spinning frequently so you donâ€™t lock up the UI, that kind of thing. PETE:Â  You can imagine [inaudible] and all the rest of them are going to be able to do a lot more smart stuff once they have this object that represents an asynchronous computation. Iâ€™m wondering, do you think thereâ€™s something to Jasmine almost intentionally making it difficult to test asynchronous code to discourage people from having asynchronous code? PETE:Â  I donâ€™t know. I can share. My viewpoint is in other languages maybe you can do that, but with JavaScript you donâ€™t have any options. You canâ€™t block. You canâ€™t spawn a thread. You canâ€™t do anything. Anything that touches the outside world, essentially, has to be asynchronous. You canâ€™t avoid it. MERRICK:Â  Yeah. PETE:Â  So it would seem a bit of a funny philosophy. My guess, my take as to why they do it that way, is just the baggage of a very mature codebase, written reasonably mature codebase. Itâ€™s hard to change that stuff. And my sense is that Mocha has got one strong, opinionated maintainer whoâ€™s happy to just go in there and make big changes, but Jasmine has had a few maintainers over time and itâ€™s a large codebase at this point. MERRICK:Â  Yeah, theyâ€™d break a lot of people if they just switch, too. PETE:Â  Yeah. MERRICK:Â  Got it. CHUCK:Â  So are you typically testing this on a Rails backend or a Node backend? Or I guess it probably doesnâ€™t really matter. PETE:Â  Yeah, thatâ€™s my point. All of this stuff that Iâ€™m talking about is really about unit tests. So the whole point here is that you donâ€™t, just because in production itâ€™s an asynchronous operation, a truly asynchronous Iâ€™m hitting the network or Iâ€™m waiting for a mouse click or whatever type of operation does not mean that in your unit tests it has to be asynchronous. So you donâ€™t need to standup a fake server. You donâ€™t need to standup a little whatever. All you need to do is fake out the asynchronicity in your unit tests. But thatâ€™s a different type of test. There, youâ€™re actually fundamentally testing something thatâ€™s asynchronous rather than faking out the asynchronous parts while youâ€™re testing stuff thatâ€™s not fundamentally asynchronous. CHUCK:Â  Right, youâ€™re acceptance testing or integration testing as opposed to PETE:Â  Unit testing, yeah. One of the definitions of the unit test is it doesn't touch the outside world. It doesn't hit a disk, doesn't hit the network, doesn't talk to a database, doesn't write to a screen. So if you're not doing any of that stuff and if the thing that you're testing isn't doing all of that stuff, then you shouldn't have to do anything fundamentally asynchronous. Youâ€™ll need to fake out the asynchronous stuff because the thing you're testing interacts with the world, the thing you're testing talks to the DOM or talks to the network, but that doesn't mean that when you're testing it, it has to do that. Testing it, you can isolate it and use promises or just raw callbacks and fake that stuff out. In this article, I mention this pattern called The Humble Object. This guy, I think he's an [x4] worker actually. Gerard Meszaros wrote this awesome book called, actually wait, is he the same guy? Iâ€™m getting him mixed up with someone else. But I think they're both [x4] workers. So he describes this idea of this humble object which is trying to move all of your asynchronous stuff into a separate place that's very, very simple and doesn't contain any logic and have the logic part that you want to test be synchronous. So that goes back to example I had of tax calculation. Make the business logic of tax calculations separate. MERRICK:Â  Sure. CHUCK:Â  Alright, well are there any other tricks to this that we haven't talked about before we get to the picks? AJ:Â  I just want to chime in with saying that I think that Pete's absolutely right about the idea of trying to look at your code and see how you can separate pieces out into synchronous bits and then of course there is that underlying caution of if the code is meant to be synchronous. If itâ€™s meant to be asynchronous, if itâ€™s some sort of asynchronous library, obviously that wonâ€™t work. But for a lot of the unit testing and the algorithm logic type stuff, thatâ€™s a really cool idea. PETE:Â  Yeah, and itâ€™s a specific example of this more broader pattern that touched on this, is this idea of hexagonal architectures, also called ports and adapters by a very clever guy called Alistair.Cockburn. Itâ€™s not pronounced the way itâ€™s written. [Chuckles] Anyway, sorry, that was my own personal joke to myself. PETE:Â  Yeah, talking about this with regards to Rails, but the same applies to all software. So this is the idea of anything where your app is integrating with a third-party thing. So thatâ€™s like jQuery or the DOM or AJAX or whatever. You want to push that to the boundaries of your system and very aggressively isolate. Have explicit â€œThis is my code that maps the outside world into my application world,â€ and push it out to the boundaries of your system and then all of the gooey center of your application doesnâ€™t have any implementation, any technical stuff in there. So it doesnâ€™t know about the idea of AJAX calls or the DOM or jQuery. It just knows about application concepts like updating the UI or asking some repository for information about a user. And maybe that user is coming from local storage or maybe that userâ€™s coming from the network. But really, the internals of your application, the majority of your application, shouldnâ€™t be thinking about things like local storage. It should be pretty agnostic to that stuff. And you can simulate things coming in and out. And you donâ€™t have to think about the boring technical gunk of AJAX requests or the weird API in the DOM or anything like that. Iâ€™m going to take two seconds to get on my soapbox. I have this theory. So the Rails community went through this slightly painful realization in the last couple of years that if you build all of your application in the context of Rails then it turns out itâ€™s really hard to not have it all be in Rails. And itâ€™s really hard to test it quickly and itâ€™s hard to break it up into pieces.
